fields.label: Air Passenger Duty (APD)
fields.infoText:
APD is a charge which is levied on the carriage, from a UK airport, of chargeable passengers on chargeable aircraft. 

From 1 April 2013, APD has been extended to include business jets and other smaller aircraft. 

For detailed guidance please see Notice 550 'Air Passenger Duty’.

For a copy, follow the link below, or phone the HM Revenue and Customs Helpline on 0300 200 3700.

Air Passenger Duty ---Link-----
**What this means**

If you operate an aircraft with an authorised take-off weight of 5.7 tonnes or more and you carry chargeable passengers, then you will be required to register for APD within 7 days of any flight occurring.
**Chargeable passengers**

Most people on your aircraft will be chargeable passengers for APD and you will need to include them in your calculations. Crew, and children under the age of 2, who don't have their own seat are exempt from APD and should not be included in your calculation.
**Chargeable aircrafts**

A chargeable aircraft is a fixed wing aircraft with an authorised take-off weight of 5.7 tonnes or more that is fuelled by avtur.

Helicopters and aircraft fuelled by avgas are excluded from APD.
**How to register and account for APD**

If you only make occasional flights you may be eligible to use the Occasional Operator Scheme. 

If you do not qualify for the Occasional Operator Scheme, you must fill in a registration form APD1 'Application to register' and send it to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
**Who can use the Occasional Operator Scheme?**

You can use the Occasional Operator Scheme if:

• you are not likely to make more than 12 flights a year from UK airports

• your estimated total duty for a year is less than £5,000
**The Occasional Operator Scheme**

If you are eligible to use the Occasional Operator Scheme you should fill in the following form which is a combined registration and payment form. 

You should send your form and cheque (if appropriate) to us within 7 days of the departure date. 

If you prefer, you may send us all of the information contained on the form on any other document provided you sign, date and declare that the information is true and complete. 

_____THIS LAST SENTENCE NEEDS TO GO________
**Pay electronically**

We recommend that you make payment electronically by Bacs or CHAPS. 

You should phone us on 03000 572 666 or email us on apd.oos@hmrc.gsi.gov.uk to get the bank details and a unique reference number to make your payment. 

Do not use this phone number for any other reason.
**Pay by cheque**

If you prefer to pay by cheque, make your cheque payable to 'HM Revenue and Customs only' and put a line through any remaining space on the 'Pay' line.

Please send your cheque with your completed form.
**Further advice**

For more information about APD follow the link below, or phone the HM Revenue and Customs Helpline on 0300 200 3700.

Air Passenger Duty ____LINK____
If you need any help filling in this form, please phone the APD Central Assurance Team on 03000 533 575 or email APDHelpdesk@hmrc.gsi.gov.uk.

This form covers an accounting period of 24 hours starting at the beginning of the day.

If more than 1 flight occurs within an accounting period, you only need to fill in 1 form. 

Fill in a new form for each new accounting period.

fields.infoText: The duty is equal to the number of chargeable passengers multiplied by the appropriate rate for the band of the destination country.

fields.label: Duty payable
fields.infoText:
**Example 1**

You are operating a Cessna Citation III, with a certified maximum take-off weight of 9,980kg. It carries 2 crew members and has seating for 6 passengers. You are returning to Nice, France, which is in Band A and you are carrying 3 passengers home who came to the UK for a meeting.  Your duty will be: 3 (passengers) x £13 (Band A, reduced rate as lowest class of travel with less than 40-inch seat pitch) = £39 APD due.

**Example 2**

You are operating a Gulfstream G550, with a certified maximum take-off weight of 42,000kg. It carries 4 crew members and has seating for 16 passengers. You are based in Canada, near Toronto, and are returning there with 5 passengers who were in the UK to watch a football match. Your duty will be: 5 (passengers) x £426 (Band B, higher rate as weight greater than 20 tonnes and seating for fewer than 19 passengers) = £2,130 APD due.

**Please note:**

If you think you may do this trip or similar 2 times or more in a year, then you should consider registering for APD (see 'About this form' page). 

**APD rates** 

The reduced rates apply where passengers are carried in the lowest class of travel on any flight unless the seat pitch exceeds 1.016 metres (40 inches), in which case, either the standard or higher rates apply. 

The standard rates apply where passengers are carried in any class of travel other than the lowest or where the seat pitch exceeds 1.016 metres (40 inches), unless the conditions for the higher rate below are met. 

The higher rates apply where passengers are carried on aircraft with an authorised take-off weight of 20 tonnes or more and equipped to carry fewer than 19 passengers. 

**APD rates from 1 April 2015**
  
Destination bands and distance from London (miles) 
                            (reduced/standard/higher)  

 Band A (0-2,000)     £13     £26    £78  
    
Band (over 2,000)    £71     £142 £426   

**For Northern Ireland only**

APD rates from 1 April 2015 on flights from Northern Ireland Destination bands and distance from London (miles)  

Direct flights (reduced/standard/higher)   

Band A (0-2,000)         £13/£26/£78 
                                                                 
Band B (2,001-4,000)    £0/£0/£0   

Indirect or connected flights (reduced/standard/higher)

Band A (0-2,000)         £13/£26/£78

Band B (over 2,000)    £71/£142/£426 
    
**Please note** 

The rates shown in the tables above are correct for flights that take off from a UK airport from 1 April 2015. However, rates are liable to change and you should check that you use the most recent rates when filling in this form.
